column1: The federal Hyde Amendment, passed in 1977, bans state use of federal Medicaid dollars to pay for abortions unless the pregnancy is the result of rape or incest, or the abortion is "necessary to save the life of the woman." States can use their own funds to cover other medically necessary abortions - usually defined by states as those to protect the physical or mental health of the woman - for Medicaid beneficiaries. Overall, 34 states and DC follow the Hyde amendment standards, 1 state, South Dakota, does not follow Hyde standards and only pays for abortions when necessary to protect a woman's life, while 15 states pay for all or other medically necessary abortions.

On June 24, 2022, the Supreme Court overturned  Roe v. Wade, eliminating the federal standard protecting the right to abortion and returning the regulation of abortion to the states. A number of states have laws banning abortions that predate the Roe v. Wade decision but it is unclear whether they are now in effect. Some states enacted laws after the Roe ruling that ban abortions and were designed to be "triggered" and take effect automatically once Roe was overturned. Other states have enacted laws that would [protect](https://www.kff.org/womens-health-policy/issue-brief/state-actions-to-protect-and-expand-access-to-abortion-services/) access to abortion. (As of July 7, 2022).

KFF analysis of Guttmacher Institute, State Policies in Brief, "[State Funding of Abortion Under Medicaid](https://www.guttmacher.org/state-policy/explore/state-funding-abortion-under-medicaid)," as of May 1, 2022.
1. This total does not include South Dakota, which does not follow Hyde standards and only pays for abortions when necessary to protect a woman's life.
2. An Alaska law that defines medically necessary is permanently blocked by a court.
3. Despite a court order, the Arizona state Medicaid program does not pay for medically necessary abortions.
4. Indiana, Utah, and Wisconsin provide state funds for abortions that are necessary to prevent damage to the woman’s physical health.
5. Iowa governor must approve any abortion paid for by the Medicaid program.
6. Iowa, Mississippi, Virginia provide state funds for abortions in cases of fetal impairment.
7. South Dakota only pays for abortions when necessary to protect the patient's life.
8. West Virginia provides state funds for abortions that are necessary to prevent damage to the woman’s physical health and in cases of fetal impairment.
